abstracts.cdata!:
While the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and the
            institutional development impact negligible. This is so,
            mainly because without additional measures undertaken to
            strengthen the operations of the Kenya Power and Lighting
            Company (KPLC), possibly through privatization/contract
            management, the sustainability of the power sector
            operations will be uncertain. Similarly, while the
            Government's commitment to implement the project was
            strong, it was however, weak in executing the institutional,
            and policy actions required. Lessons question the provision
            of emergency recovery support, where policy and
            institutional factors have played a role in bringing about a
            crisis situation, and if so, whether such support should be
            accompanied by reform conditions. The experience with this
            operation supports the notion that the decision should be
            based on the implications of the "with" and
            "without" emergency support scenarios on growth,
            and poverty. But since the design of emergency operations
            require implementation of mitigation measures, the
            policy/institutional related causes of the emergency would
            need to be addressed to avoid repeat disasters. Thus, by
            linking measures to implement reforms, stakeholders would be
            sensitized on important sector policy issues, and, the
            Borrower should be required to commit irreversible actions
            to be taken prior to financing approval.
